texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: While using a Dell R720 at work today, we stumbled upon a problem where the  predictable network device naming with systemd  gave us some unpredictable results. The server has four onboard network ports (two 10GbE and two 1GbE) and an add-on 10GbE card with two additional ports.
texts.text: While using a Dell R720 at work today, we stumbled upon a problem where the  predictable network device naming with systemd  gave us some unpredictable results. The server has four onboard network ports (two 10GbE and two 1GbE) and an add-on 10GbE card with two additional ports.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# lspci | grep Eth
01:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
01:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
08:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
08:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
42:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
42:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
texts.text:
# lspci | grep Eth
01:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
01:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
08:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
08:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
42:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)
42:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Controller 10-Gigabit X540-AT2 (rev 01)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're not familiar with that output, it says:
texts.text: If you're not familiar with that output, it says:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Two 10GbE ports on PCI bus 1 (ports 0 and 1)
texts.text: Two 10GbE ports on PCI bus 1 (ports 0 and 1)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Two 1GbE ports on PCI bus 8 (ports 0 and 1)
texts.text: Two 1GbE ports on PCI bus 8 (ports 0 and 1)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Two 10GbE ports on PCI bus 42 (ports 0 and 1)
texts.text: Two 10GbE ports on PCI bus 42 (ports 0 and 1)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When the system boots up, the devices are named based on  systemd-udevd's criteria . Our devices looked like this after boot:
texts.text: When the system boots up, the devices are named based on  systemd-udevd's criteria . Our devices looked like this after boot:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ip addr | egrep ^[0-9]
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default
2: enp8s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
3: enp8s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
4: enp1s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP group default qlen 1000
5: enp1s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
6: enp66s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
7: enp66s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
texts.text:
# ip addr | egrep ^[0-9]
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default
2: enp8s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
3: enp8s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
4: enp1s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP group default qlen 1000
5: enp1s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
6: enp66s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000
7: enp66s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN group default qlen 1000

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Devices 2-5 make sense since they're on PCI buses 1 and 8. However, our two-port NIC on PCI bus 42 has suddenly been named 66. We rebooted the server with the  rd.udev.debug  kernel command line to display debug messages from systemd-udevd during boot. That gave us this:
texts.text: Devices 2-5 make sense since they're on PCI buses 1 and 8. However, our two-port NIC on PCI bus 42 has suddenly been named 66. We rebooted the server with the  rd.udev.debug  kernel command line to display debug messages from systemd-udevd during boot. That gave us this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# journalctl | grep enp66s0f0
systemd-udevd[471]: renamed network interface eth0 to enp66s0f0
systemd-udevd[471]: NAME 'enp66s0f0' /usr/lib/udev/rules.d/80-net-setup-link.rules:13
systemd-udevd[471]: changing net interface name from 'eth0' to 'enp66s0f0'
systemd-udevd[471]: renamed netif to 'enp66s0f0'
systemd-udevd[471]: changed devpath to '/devices/pci0000:40/0000:40:02.0/0000:42:00.0/net/enp66s0f0'
texts.text:
# journalctl | grep enp66s0f0
systemd-udevd[471]: renamed network interface eth0 to enp66s0f0
systemd-udevd[471]: NAME 'enp66s0f0' /usr/lib/udev/rules.d/80-net-setup-link.rules:13
systemd-udevd[471]: changing net interface name from 'eth0' to 'enp66s0f0'
systemd-udevd[471]: renamed netif to 'enp66s0f0'
systemd-udevd[471]: changed devpath to '/devices/pci0000:40/0000:40:02.0/0000:42:00.0/net/enp66s0f0'

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: So the system sees that the enp66s0f0 device is actually on PCI bus 42. What gives? A quick trip to #systemd on Freenode caused a facepalm:
texts.text: So the system sees that the enp66s0f0 device is actually on PCI bus 42. What gives? A quick trip to #systemd on Freenode caused a facepalm:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
mhayden | weird, udev shows it on pci bus 42 but yet names it 66
    jwl | 0x42 = 66
texts.text:
mhayden | weird, udev shows it on pci bus 42 but yet names it 66
    jwl | 0x42 = 66

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I didn't expect to see hex. Sure enough, converting 42 in hex to decimal yields 66:
texts.text: I didn't expect to see hex. Sure enough, converting 42 in hex to decimal yields 66:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That also helps to explain why the devices on buses 1 and 8 were unaffected. Converting 1 and 8 in hex to decimal gives 1 and 8. If you're new to hex, this  conversion table  may help.
texts.text: That also helps to explain why the devices on buses 1 and 8 were unaffected. Converting 1 and 8 in hex to decimal gives 1 and 8. If you're new to hex, this  conversion table  may help.

texts.label: paragraph
